The need to be involved with their children at very young ages, the need to know what the developmental milestones are.

Mandatory minimum sentences, sentencing guideline systems, some other movements over the last couple of decades in sentencing reform were a valid leap for trying to create a more uniform system of sentencing, trying to prevent different judges from coming up with disparate results often driven by liberal forces saying there's a risk that…
Mm-hmm.
…white offenders would get the benefits if judges had a lot of discretion.

The problem has been to try to regulate the discretion of judges alone isn't sensitive to the discretion that prosecutors have, the discretion that other actors in the criminal justice system have and even more, generally, some of the structural realities that influence how the criminal justice system operates so that disproportionately it ends up being African-American offenders who are subject to the harshest of these mandatory sentencing terms.
And by structural factors, are you talking about things like poverty?
Poverty, urban-versus-rural realities.
One, for example, that's so interesting comes from a recent report by a terrific commission in New Jersey.

The New Jersey Sentencing Commission did some dramatic report about drug-free school zones - we think makes perfect sense - increased the penalties in the vicinity of a school for any drug dealing there.
But in urban areas, schools are more closely packed together, and there are some inner city regions where you can't get outside of a drug-free school zone.
Mm-hmm.

And so it ends up being that anybody who lives in those urban areas at any point, even if they're not trying to sell the kids or not trying to be near a school, are subject to these enhanced penalties based on this desire to make school zones a special place deserving with special punishments.
Another example that people point to is death row, and the disparities there are equally shocking.
Yeah.
And there, what's interesting, particularly, is the way in which the race of the victim has a profound impact.

And one of the things that's, again, sort of, hard to understand and yet important to appreciate is often times it's not discrimination in terms of being uniquely severe to African-American offenders as much as it is being uniquely lenient to white offenders or perhaps disturbingly lenient when a white offender is guilty of having a black offender as a victim.
And so, what we really see the most dramatic statistics come in sentencings, when we have a white defendant who kills a black victim.

In fact, in the modern history of the death penalty, where there's been close to eleven hundred executions, there have only been 15 white defendants who have been executed, having committed a crime in which they kill a black defendant.
Mm-hmm.
But when we changed the racial dynamics, a black defendant having killed a white victim, we now have 223 such executions when it's that ratio.

And so in other words, it seems, though, if you just look at the execution numbers, it's, you know, 10 to 15 times more likely that you'll end up executed if you are a black defendant who kills a white victim rather than a white defendant who kills a black victim.
And I wonder, is there any analysis that shows that African-Americans get better treatment from African-American judges?
Not really.

In fact, there are some interesting statistics that suggests that African-American judges will sometimes be harsher, and there are some particularly notable research that's now coming out that is not necessarily skin color as much as it is sort of relationship to visions of racial threats that having, quote, unquote, ""certain kinds of facial features."" They're seen as more threatening than others - in part, can account for how some of these plays out.

And again, that reminds me when I look at this that there's a deeper psychology at work and there are these structural issues that I think are hurt if we try to interpret this data and say, aha, the system racist and the problem is, you know, the whites are making rules that they're treating blacks unfairly.
I think it - these statistics demand nuance to understand how they come to be and will require nuanced solutions to deal with the problems that they reveal.
